description: a(n) = number of lattice paths from (0,0,0) to (n,n,n) along the cracks on the surface of a Rubik-ized n X n X n cube so that no step increases distance from goal.
comments: 3-dimensional version of block-walking (0,0) to (n,n) in binomial(2n,n) ways.
links: Harry J. Smith, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..200
W. Li and E. T. H. Wang, A bug's shortest path on a cube, Mathematics Magazine 58:4 (Sept. 1985), pp. 219-221.
example: a(1)=6: XYZ, XZY, YXZ, YZX, ZXY, ZYX
maple: A060774 := proc(n)        6*(binomial(3*n,n)-binomial(2*n,n)) ;end proc: # _R. J. Mathar_, Oct 31 2015
prog: (PARI) j=[]; for(n=1,50,j=concat(j,6*(binomial(3*n,n)-binomial(2*n,n)))); j(PARI) { for (n=1, 200, write("b060774.txt", n, " ", 6*(binomial(3*n, n) - binomial(2*n, n))); ) } [From _Harry J. Smith_, Jul 11 2009]
author: _Len Smiley_, Apr 25 2001
extensions: Corrected by Franklin T. Adams-Watters and _T. D. Noe_, Oct 25 2006
